bibl.title: Letter from John J. Moran to Philip Showalter Hench, December 18, 1937

div1.p: Moran writes to Hench about his own health, the various interpretations of the yellow fever story, and his part in the experiments.

div1.head: Letter from John J. Moran to Philip Showalter Hench, December 18, 1937
div1.opener:
Havana, Dec. 18, 1937.
Dr. Philip S. Hench,
MAYO CLINIC,
Rochester, Minn.
My dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
You will be thinking of me as an ingrate for my failure to
reply to your letter of September 22nd wherein you so kindly offer to assist
Kissinger and myself in having our connection with the yellow fever experiments
made known in all its details to the medical profession. Please know that I
appreciate more than my ability to express it in words the offer made in your
letter. First off, however, I want you to know that my failure to reply to
your letter at once was due to the fact that I have had no heart to write for
the better part of three months. I have been suffering from an old ailment,
discovery of which came about for the first time in Bordeaux during the World
War, namely, an ulcer of the duodenum. An X-Ray examination at the Mass.
General Hospital Unit, near Bordeaux, revealed its existence. I think that
Unit was known as Base Hospital No. 6. On recommendation of the major surgeon
who examined me, I was to be “Deed” back to the United States so that I could be
operated upon at Walter Reed General Hospital. With or without reason, I con-
sidered it a disgrace to be D'd back and fought it, requesting as a last resort
an interview with the Colonel commanding the Base Hospital. He, too, was
adamant until I played my last card. That was my connection with the yellow
fever experiments, an episode with which he appeared entirely familiar. I had
my way upon promising that when and as I should get back to the United States
I would go to Washington and have the operation performed. I never did. On
and off, thru the intervening years, I have been subject to attacks. This last
one, while not the most severe, lasted longer than any of the previous ones.
An operation now, at age 62, would be out of the question as I take it. I am
reasonably certain that I could not survive it. My better half wanted me to
write to you for advice from the world's most famous clinic but I refrained from
doing so. I am morally certain that I would be welcome to your advice free of
charge. I hesitated to seek your advice because I know that the medical pro-
fession frowns on treatment by correspondence. My mainstay, thruout the years,
have been P. D. & Co's “Milk of Bismuth” in the acute period of the attacks and
“Neutralon with Belladonna” (Schering & Kahlbaum) as a more or less steady diet.

I will now pass to the subject matter of your very kind
letter. You need be in no hurry to return printed matter I sent to you some
months ago. When you have finished with them, whenever that may be, will be
time enough. You are entirely correct in arriving at the conclusion that
the yellow fever story has not been correctly told so far. I know that it has
been distorted. One thing only is certain and that is that Doctor Walter Reed
was the guiding spirit in that famous drama. Thruout the years other idols
have been set up to share in the honors which posterity should accord to be
his exclusively. Intimately associated with Reed and his work as I was, I
am none the less barred from telling the true story. As a non-medical man the
telling of the true story does not fall within my province. Cuba, for instance,
claims for Finlay ALL THE CREDIT for Walter Reed's findings and our American
medicos have permitted the Cubans to steal the show in behalf of Finlay at the
meetings of the Pan-American Medical Association had in recent years. Even
Agramonte, notwithstanding the article published by him in the Scientific
Monthly, in 1915, proclaimed Finlay as the real discoverer in the latter years
of his life. In the year 1928 I discussed this matter at length with Doctor
Agramonte, pointing out to him the discrepancy between his then point of view

Dec. 18, 1937.
and that which he held in 1915 in the article he contributed to the “Scientific
Monthly” entitled “The Inside History of a Great Medical Discovery”. He was
completely taken aback by my reference to that article and I sensed that he did
not know I was familiar with it or had ever read it. By all this, please do
not think I am trying to rob Finlay of all the glory to which he is entitled
for his contribution to Reed's eventual findings. Reed himself acknowledged in
full Finlay's claims in the premises. True to the memory of the immortal Reed,
I have always been willing to accord to Finlay his just measure and share in the
eventual and conclusive results. The Cuban medical profession have consistently
refrained from even mentioning Reed except when it was unavoidable. The medical
profession in the United States have passively permitted the Cubans to grow bolder
and bolder in their glorifying of Finlay as against the master, Reed. Since
Gorgas' work in Cuba did not run counter to their claims for Finlay, they accord
him the honors which they know are Reed's, in addition to the honors which Gorgas
won as a sanitarian, based on Reed's findings. I am merely calling a “spade”
a “spade”, nothing more. The Cuban medicos have made it a life business to
laud Finlay, so much so that the present generation of medicos in Cuba ignore
Reed entirely. In contrast, American medicos who write or lecture on Reed and
his work, fail to get the picture and in many instances present that which they
have hurriedly prepared as the “inside or true story” of the real discoverer of
the mode of transmission of yellow fever. Who but the immortal Reed and his
master mind conceived the idea of the “human guinea pig” as the medium thru
which the mosquito theory could be exploded or established as a fact. No, my
friend, the real story of “Walter Reed and Yellow Fever” has never been properly
written, with all due respect to Dr. Howard A. Kelly and his book so entitled.

Now, my dear doctor, I will pass to your suggestion that
Kissinger and myself write our respective accounts of the part we played in the
yellow fever experiments. I am greatly honored by your offer to assist us
to such an end and to have our versions published in some accredited medical journal.
To me, however, anything more than a passing reference to my share in the
experiments would be out of order. With Reed as the central figure, I should
be glad to colaborate with you or any other American medico in placing the real
story before the medical profession in the United States. Kissinger and myself
are not even among the “lesser lights” in any such proposed article. The lesser
lights would be Carroll, Lazear and Agramonte, the other three members of the
Yello Fever Board. Kissinger and myself, including the other sixteen who vol-
unteered for the experiments, would be entitled to such reference as “human
guinea pigs” should be accorded.. We have both had a full share of fame or
glory from the modest parts we played in the experiments. I, for my part, am
satisfied that full justice has been done to me and my contribution to the work
of Walter Reed. If I have had more than my share of publicity for my modest
part in Reed's findings, I can truthfully state that I never sought publicity.
It came to me unsolicited. When I sent you a lengthy story of my life, I
did so to the end that you might be able to form an estimate of me personally
for the address you had in mind for the members of the Mayo Clinic. I did not
have in mind the possibility of having your article published unless, perhaps,
the Mayo Clinic has a publication of its own for local circulation. Nor did
I calculate that there would be any lengthy reference to myself in your article.
I gave you more than you asked for, with the idea that reference to my share in
the experiments would be “boiled down” to a few pertinent paragraphs. I belive
that at least half of the eighteen men who volunteered for the exeperiments are
still living. I will send you the addresses of two of them within a few days.
Meantime, I remain, with kind personal regards,
div1.closer:
Sincerely, John J. Moran A Merry Xmas and a happy
New Year to You.
